awd_titl_txt: IGE: Graduate Opportunities to Learn Data Science (GOLD): Empowering female and underrepresented graduate students through inclusive data science training
awd_abstract_narration:
The amount of data generated by modern scientific research is unprecedented. While this leads to technological advances and scientific discoveries, it also creates a dire need for a workforce with data science skills. In addition, society needs a more diverse science workforce, as creative and robust scientific and technological advances result from more diverse scientific teams. With the right approach, we can train diverse basic science graduate students in data science to fill these workforce needs. This National Science Foundation Innovations of Graduate Education (IGE) award to San Francisco State University will evaluate a novel, modular approach for inclusive graduate education to advance data science skills in the basic sciences. The Graduate Opportunities to Learn Data science (GOLD) strategy will support basic science Masters students, focusing on women and students from historically underrepresented groups, to (1) learn computational and statistical skills, (2) apply those skills to their research projects, and (3) form strong learning and networking communities. This new approach will create inclusive environments that prepare diverse students to obtain the interdisciplinary skills necessary to boost their career development. The GOLD program is modular, so successful components can easily be adopted at other universities, creating the potential for a significant impact on graduate education. 

The Graduate Opportunities to Learn Data science (GOLD) strategy will be implemented through a 12-unit interdisciplinary certificate program. The program includes a 9-unit series of courses that will teach programming and data science, using assignments and examples drawn from biology and chemistry research. A 1-unit class taken twice will help students to apply these skills to their own thesis research supported by peer-mentors. A 1-unit professional development class will connect students with local computational biologists and chemists working in academia and industry, helping the students network and contextualize their training. To ensure an inclusive environment, GOLD will (1) use validated methods to mitigate well-known barriers that alienate many women and underrepresented students entering high-tech fields and (2) provide faculty professional development on inclusive teaching strategies, active learning, and mentoring. The success of the GOLD strategy will be assessed based on five student outcomes using a mixed methods approach: acquisition of computational skills, application of computational skills, career goals, perception of inclusive learning environments, and scientific identity. Outcomes will contribute to the current state of pedagogy in graduate education and enable successful implementation of similar programs. 

The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How the GOLD certificate program started

Around 2018, undergraduate students in our departments (Biology and Chemistry) had the option to participate in the PINC computing minor, and it wasn’t long before graduate students began asking for similar opportunities. At the time, several of us computational scientists were already collaborating on initiatives like a computational summer program, united by our shared passion for data science, teaching, and promoting equity and diversity. During one of our classes with graduate students, we decided to conduct an informal survey: Who would be interested in a certificate program in data science? Many hands shot up. Encouraged by the enthusiasm, we decided to pursue NSF funding to make it happen.

What could go wrong? 

We wanted to offer data science skills to our master’s students, but from the beginning were aware of all the things that could go wrong. A. We were worried that only students with prior coding experience would join the program. B. We were worried that students would not sign up if they thought the program was too daunting (e.g., too many units). C. We were worried that the program would not be attractive to certain demographics, especially women of color. D. We were worried that offering the program would turn out to be too much work for our departments. 

How did we design the program? 

We tried to balance usefulness and doability. We ended up with a program that included 4 classes: In semester 1, students would take a 3-unit computing in Python class. In semester 2, students would take a 4-unit data science in R class. In semester 3, students would take a 1-unit class on careers in data science and a 1-unit coding support class. Finally, to make this a 12-unit certificate we included a semester of research in the requirements, but since all our master students need to take several semesters of research anyways, this doesn’t increase their workload. 

Does it work? 

Yes. We designed the program including three new data science classes. Since 2020, we have had between 30 and 40 students in the program each year, which is around half of the master students in Biology and Chemistry/Biochemistry. The program is also doable for the departments. The first class (the Python class) is offered by Computer Science. The other classes are offered by Biology or Chemistry/Biochemistry. There is enough interest amongst our faculty to teach the classes. In fact, this year (2024), none of the original people who designed the program are teaching in it. 

How did the pandemic affect our efforts? 

The launch date for GOLD was fall 2020. Obviously, the pandemic changed many things. We couldn’t do all the activities we had planned, especially professional development we had planned for faculty. However, for the students, the pandemic sped up the rolling out of the GOLD program. We had originally planned to only enroll a pilot cohort of 10 students in 2020, but because our campus was closed and many students couldn’t do the experimental work they had planned, there was a lot of interest in the GOLD program and we enrolled almost 40 students that first year. 

Issues and pitfalls

The GOLD program has changed our graduate programs. We estimate that about half of our master students enroll in the program. But that doesn’t mean that there are no issues. A) The 1-unit classes are good for the students, but hard to staff because most of our classes are 3 units and 1 unit doesn’t count enough. B) We are always worried that with the four-class schedule, the students are not exposed to enough topics and skills. For example, they don’t take machine learning, statistics or sequence analysis. C) The success of the GOLD program classes has led to reduced enrollment in “real” biology classes which worries some faculty. D) Because we only offer GOLD classes only once a year, students need to sign up for the Python class in their first semester. If they miss that opportunity it is much harder for them to do the program. 

Conclusion

Thanks to our previous experience, high student interest, support from our departments and an NSF grant, we were able to design a certificate program that allows a large fraction of our graduate students to learn coding and data science skills.
